posts.cooked: GitHub - yahn1609/3004swerve3 this is our github GitHub - CranberryAlarm/CA24_RobotCode: Cranberry Alarm's 2024 Robot in 3 Days (Ri3D) code cranberry alarm github Onshape We are using the cranberry alarm intake but with talonfx instead of canspark max and are using swerve we just need to make sure our subsystems our good I cant try the code right now but any changes or help or advice would be appreciated

link_counts.title: GitHub - CranberryAlarm/CA24_RobotCode: Cranberry Alarm's 2024 Robot in 3 Days (Ri3D) code

posts.name: Erik Orlowski
posts.cooked:
Everything looks reasonable to me. The only think that made me pause is you have a bunch of boolean arguments in your subsystems that don’t look like they’re really doing anything right now.

Of course, the only way to actually know if any of this will work is to run it on the robot. You could also try simulating your code (documentation here and here ). The simulation can at least confirm that motors are moving when you want them to. Especially with a swerve drive and position control on your intake arm though, you’ll want to test on the physical robot as soon as you can.

link_counts.title: Introduction to Robot Simulation — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked: Hi I’m the teams programmer, thank you for your advice and input. Were pretty new to Command Base and looked up tutorials to help such as FRC 0 to Autonomous, which used primarily booleans in their intakesubsystem. Is there anyway that we can improve upon this boolean esque issue? Or better improve the quality of our code in general.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: One thing I would suggest when dealing with enums is to not use a switch statement like you did, but rather store data inside of the enum class for each enum. You can do this with a constructor for the enum and a sort of class variable. This is an example from our code
